Metal-support electronic interaction is a feasible way to enhance the catalytic activity and bifunctionality for oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), and further the easily water electrolysis for hydrogen production at low cost. Herein, NiFe alloy embedded in N doped carbon support hybrid (NiFe@NC) was prepared by pyrolysis of metal ions impregnated bamboo precursor. In this NiFe@NC hybrid, the surface (oxy)hydroxide layer of alloy led to high OER efficiency (overpotential of 270 mV at 10 mA cm−2), and the alloy-support interaction enabled high catalytic efficiency for HER (overpotential of 206 mV at −10 mA cm−2). Benefitted by the bifunctional features, the symmetric water electrolyzer based on two identical NiFe@NC electrodes demonstrated acceptable input voltage and high faradaic efficiencies (FEs) for water electrolysis. The current work offers a feasible showcase for fulfilling of bifunctional catalyses in water electrolysis via the metal-support electronic interaction. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords NiFe alloy Metal-support electronic interaction Charge redistribution Oxygen evolution reaction Hydrogen evolution reaction Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Hydrogen is a future carbon-neutral fuel with high specific energy (140 MJ kg−1) and zero carbon emission [1,2], which is especially valuable for application in driving power source for heavy machinery and popular traffic tools by virtue of the superb gravimetric energy density. The efficient and green hydrogen production technique is a vital prerequisite for actual popularization of hydrogen fuel. Relative to the current steam methane reforming for hydrogen production with inevitable generation of carbon oxides, the electric- or photo- driven water splitting is undoubtedly more promising for practical application [3,4]. Thereinto, water electrolysis is a easily-controllable approach for hydrogen production using clean electric energy with high utilization ratio, therefore has attracted enormous investigation enthusiasm [5,6]. In term of water electrolysis, the multi-electrons and multi-steps processes of OER and HER with sluggish kinetics restrict the overall electric energy utilization ratio and hydrogen production economy [7,8]. In this context, it is highly paramount to develop efficient catalysts to expedite the kinetics of OER, HER and reduce the water decomposition voltage [3,9]. Although RuO2 and IrO2 are reckoned as benchmark OER catalysts whilst Pt/C is advanced HER catalyst, the inhibitive costs and low reserves of noble metal resources limit their industrial-scale applications in water electrolysis. To solve these challenges, the exploration of cost-effective bifunctional catalysts are extremely imperative [10]. Due to the similar valence electron configurations to Pt, Ru and Ir, iron series metals (Fe, Co, Ni) based compounds such as oxides [11,12], (oxy)hydroxides [10,13], sulfides [14,15], phosphides [16,17] and carbides [18,19] are frequently documented as non-precious catalysts for OER or HER. Generally speaking, a monocomponent catalyst engages in either oxidation or reduction reaction for the catalytic selectivity, which is not suitable for bifunctional catalyses in water electrolysis, the binary composite with heterojunction [20,21] or support loaded active component [22,23] inherits the features of both components and enables the catalytic bifunctionality [24,25]. More importantly, the interface electronic interaction due to the gap between Fermi levels creates different electrophilic and nucleophilic microregions, which promote the chemisorption, dissociation of reactants, and enhance the catalytic activities of individual microregions via the modified electronic structures [26–29]. Hence, a series of heterojunctions [20,30], Mott-Schottky junctions [31,32] and the support loaded active catalyst hybrids [33,34] were developed to enhance the oxidation/reduction bifunctional catalytic activities. In term of the doped carbon support loaded metal or alloy hybrid catalyst, the heteroatoms (commonly N) not only alter the electronic structure and improve the electric conductivity, wettability of the N doped carbon motif (denoted as NC) [35,36], but serve as coordination sites to immobilize metals and restrict their aggregation during electrochemical process [37]. On the other hand, the enriched electrons within embedded metals spontaneously diffuse across the heterointerface to NC motif to achieve a balanced state with aligned Fermi levels, thus establishes nucleophilic/electrophilic microregions responsible for the oxidative and reductive dissociation of water molecules simultaneously [38–40]. In this sense, the non-precious metal (alloy)-NC hybrids are viewed as promising bifunctional catalysts for water electrolysis. In preparation of NC motif supported metal hybrid, the pyrolysis of zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF) precursor is a common approach, but it consumes a large amount of organic solvents in the initial synthesis of ZIF precursor, which does not conform to the current green synthesis notion, so the development of more clean and economical approach is highly desired. Given the abundant natural resources and enriched heteroelements, most of biomasses can serve as self-doping precursors for preparation of NCs needless incorporation of extra heteroelement sources. Hence, the metal ions impregnated biomasses are feasible precursors for designing of metal (alloy)-NC hybrid catalysts for water electrolysis. Based on these considerations, herein, fresh bamboo was employed as C, N sources and adsorbent to suck the transition metal salts for preparation of NiFe@NC hybrid via pyrolysis treatment, and the catalytic performances of the resultant NiFe@NC for OER and HER were evaluated in alkali medium. The NiFe@NC catalytic electrode exhibited bifunctional catalytic activities and fast kinetics for water electrolysis benefitted by the interaction between NiFe alloy and NC support and surface oxidation of alloy component. The symmetric water electrolyzer based on NiFe@NC catalytic electrode demonstrated moderate driving voltage, high FEs and good durability. The current work provides a general approach to enhance OER, HER bifunctional catalytic efficiencies via the electronic interaction within alloy-NC hybrid. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of NiFe@NC Fresh bamboo trunk was obtained from our compass (Henan Normal University), which was rinsed with deionized water and dried at 80 °C, then mechanically pulverized and screened by a filter screen to obtain fine powder, which was employed as C, N sources. To prepare NiFe@NC, 2 mmol of Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O and 2 mmol of Fe(NO3)3·9 H2O were initially dissolved in 5 mL of deionized water to form a clear solution. Thereafter, 2 g of bamboo powder was immersed in the solution and continuously stirred for 24 h to sufficiently suck the salts, then dried at 80 °C to form precursor. The dry precursor was loaded in a quartz boat and placed in a N2 filled tube furnace for pyrolysis treatment at ramping rate of 5 °C min−1 to 800 °C and maintained for 2 h, the yielded black powder was ground and immersed in 1 M HCl for 5 h to eliminate the exposed metal particles, then rinsed copiously with deionized water and dried to afford NiFe@NC. The Ni, Fe alloys embedded NC hybrids at the same total mole of Ni, Fe salts (4 mmol) whereas different Ni:Fe molar ratios (2:1 and 1:2) were also prepared following the same procedure, which were denoted as Ni2Fe@NC and NiFe2@NC, respectively. In controlled experiments, 4 mmol of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 2 mmol Ni(NO3)2·6H2O+ 2 mmol Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 2 mmol Co(NO3)2·6 H2O+ 2 mmol Fe(NO3)2·9H2O were dissolved, sucked by bamboo powder separately, and pyrolyzed likewise, the afforded samples were denoted as Ni@NC, Co@NC, NiCo@NC and CoFe@NC, respectively according to the metal salts. NC was also prepared by the same procedure without sucking of any metal ions. Bare NiFe alloy was prepared by calcination of NiFe@NC at 800 °C for 1 h in air, followed by calcination another time at 400 °C for 2 h in 5% H2/Ar atmosphere. 2.2 Characterizations and electrochemical measurements The physical characterizations were shown in supporting information (section I). The electrochemical tests were performed on a CHI 760E electrochemical workstation. The 3-electrode system includes a catalyst loaded working electrode, a AgCl/Ag reference electrode (in saturated KCl inner electrolyte) and a graphite rod counter electrode in 30 mL of 1 M KOH electrolyte. The working electrode was fabricated by pasting the slurry containing of 5 mg catalyst, 1 mg Ketjen black and 20 μL Nafion onto Ni foam (1 ×1 ×0.1 cm3) current collector at a net catalyst loading amount of 0.5 mg cm−2, then pressed at 10 MP. The commercial RuO2 and Pt/C (20 wt%) electrodes were fabricated likewise. In electrochemical tests, all of the potentials (Es) were calibrated relative to reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) according to: E(vs RHE)=E(vs AgCl/Ag)+ 0.197 + 0.059 pH [41]. The polar curves for alkali OER were recorded by linear scanning voltammetry (LSVs), the response current density (J) was recorded based on the geometric area of electrode, and the Es were directly recorded and corrected by 85% inner resistance (IR) compensation. Besides, the catalytic kinetics was reflected by Tafel plots based on the logarithmic current density (logJ) versus overpotential (η) curves collected from non-compensated LSVs. The electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) was estimated by the electric double layered capacitance (C dl ) according to ECSA＝C dl /C s , herein the C dl was calculated via the slope of half cathodic-to-anode current density difference (∆J/2 =(J anodic-J cathodic)/2) from CVs against potential scan rates (5, 10, 20, 30, 50, 80 and 100 mV s−1) within non-faradic potential range (1.0–1.1 V vs RHE), and the C s stood for the specific capacitance (0.04 mF cm−2) [42]. EIS for OER was recorded at 1.6 V vs RHE over 105∼10−2 Hz with perturbation of 5 mV. The long-term catalytic stability of the electrode was recorded by chronopotentiometry (V-t curve) at J= 10 mA cm−2. HER performance was also measured by the similar method in negative potential range. To further evaluate the bifunctional catalytic behaviors of the typical NiFe@NC catalyst in water electrolysis, two identical NiFe@NC electrodes were aligned parallelly with a distance of 3 cm to form a symmetric electrolyzer in the same alkali electrolyte, which was denoted as NiFe@NC//NiFe@NC electrolyzer, the overall electrochemical response was evaluated by LSV (at 5 mV s−1). The amounts of generated H2, O2 at both electrodes were measured by water drainage method, and the FEs for H2, O2 production were calculated via: FE= (N × Z × F/Q)× 100% [24], wherein N is the mole of collected gas, Z is the transferred electrons number per mole of gas, F is Faraday constant, and Q is the input charge during electrolysis. The electrochemical stability of the electrolyzer was probed by V-t operation (at 10 mA cm−2) in 2-electrode system. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Fundamental design idea Hybrids with efficient electronic interaction is a promising way to accomplish efficient and bifunctional catalyses by creation of electrophilic and nucleophilic microregions across the contact interface. NC is an ideal support for anchoring of metal (alloy) to construct robust hybrid via the coordinative N sites and the corrosion tolerance nature of carbonaceous motif. The preparation of metal (alloy)-NC hybrid via easily-available precursor and cost-effective approach is meaningful. Bamboo contains abundant cellulose and lignin, the abundant capillaries in trunk of bamboo ensure the rapid pumping of nourishment ingredients to the branches and leaves to sustain the rapid growth, so it can serve as precursor for preparation of porous carbons for applications in water, air purification and energy storage [43,44]. Moreover, the good adaptability to various climate conditions enables bamboo an easily-available and cost-effective biomass precursor for preparation of carbonaceous materials. Herein, bamboo was employed as the C, N sources and support for preparation of NiFe@NC hybrid. As demonstrated in Fig. 1, by sufficient impregnation in Ni, Fe salts and dried, the color of bamboo powder alters from yellowish to dark green. Due to the strong oxytropic features, the metal ions are tightly and homogeneously anchored onto the inner surface of capillaries within bamboo. Undergoes pyrolysis in inert atmosphere, the metal ions experience carbothermic reduction to afford alloy clusters and granules encapsulated into the as-formed NC motif. In such a hybrid, the homogeneously self-doped N heteroatoms induce the charge redistribution within the CN motif triggered by the difference in electronegativities (χC=2.55, χN =3.04), the C-N dipoles therefore serve as catalytic sites for the chemisorption and activation of reactants [45]. In addition, the N dopant can serve as anchoring site for the tight immobilization of alloy, the efficient metal-support electronic interaction is beneficial for interface charge redistribution and further the optimization of adsorption energies for reactants and intermediates [46]. Moreover, the coordination interaction by NC inhibits the agglomeration of alloy and facilitates the homogeneous scattering of tiny alloy crystallites with sufficient exposure to reactants. In this sense, the bamboo derived NiFe@NC is envisioned to be a feasible catalyst for water electrolysis. 3.2 Structural characterizations The phases of the prepared products were initially characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD). As illustrated in Fig. 2a, the Ni@NC demonstrates three diffraction peaks at 44.5, 51.8 and 76.3 °, which are explicitly assignable to the (111), (200) and (220) planes of metallic Ni (JCPDS: 04–0850) [47], indicative of the carbothermic reduction of adsorbed Ni cations during the pyrolytic carbonization of bamboo. Likewise, the diffractions of Co@NC at 44.2, 51.5 and 75.8 ° are indexable to the (111), (200) and (220) planes of Co metal (JCPDS: 15–0806) [45]. Given the faint discrepancy in atomic radii of iron series metals, the NiCo@NC, NiFe@NC (JCPDS: 47–1417) and CoFe@NC display the similar diffraction patterns to Ni@NC (or Co@NC) but with slight deviations in diffraction angles (Fig. 2b), evidencing the formation of face-centered cubic alloys within the former samples [48–50]. Relative to Ni@NC or Co@NC, the diffractions of alloy-NC hybrids are weaker and wider, showing the reduced crystallinities for the ununiform metal bond lengths in alloys [51]. In addition, the wide band around 22 ° is indexable to the (002) planes of graphite, which is consistent with bare NC, such a diffraction evidences the carbonization of bamboo. Note that this diffraction is more legible in NiFe@NC and CoFe@NC, such traits suggest that the Fe based alloys are more efficient catalyst for graphitization of NC motif during pyrolysis process. Raman spectra of the samples feature two strong vibration bands centered at 1335 and 1595 cm−1 (Fig. 2c), which are assignable respectively to the A 1 g vibrations of defects and disordered carbon sites at the rim and doping sites (D band), as well as the E 2 g vibrations of graphitic carbon framework (G band). The D band to G band intensity ratios (I D:I Gs) are 0.97, 0.96, 1.01, 0.99, 0.98 and 1.02, respectively for Ni@NC, Co@NC, NiCo@NC, NiFe@NC, CoFe@NC and NC, the similar ratios around 1 indicate the enriched structural defects within carbon motif due to N doping and removal of partial oxygen functionalities [52]. The surface areas and pore widths of the samples were determined by N2 sorption isotherms. From Fig. 2d, all of the isotherms comprise high adsorption amounts at the low relative pressure (P/P0) and distinct hysteresis loops between adsorption and desorption branches within P/P0 > 0.5. The combined I/IV type isotherms suggest the containing of abundant micropores and mesopores, wherein the micropores with small curvature radiuses enable strong adsorptive interaction force with reactants, while the mesopores serve as diffusion channels for reactants to access the inner surface of micropores, the high mass migration rate and strong adsorptive interaction force facilitate sufficient interface reactions. The specific surface areas (SBETs) are 616, 478, 544, 495, 368 and 786 m2 g−1, respectively for Ni@NC, Co@NC, NiCo@NC, NiFe@NC, CoFe@NC and NC, the high values ensure abundant contact areas for reactants, which are essential for surface catalytic reactions. To be mentioned, the adsorption amounts of NiFe@NC and CoFe@NC are unsaturated at P/P0 = 1, which suggest the inclusion of plentiful macropores due to the more sufficient condensation of carbon motif and the collapse, coalescence of micro-/mesopores during the pyrolysis by incorporation of Fe, the abundant macropores allow the filling of reactants with short mass migration path length, which are beneficial for catalytic kinetics. The pore width distributions of the samples based on density function theory (DFT) model are shown in Fig. 2e, all of them display overwhelming micropores centered around 1 nm and mesopores within 2–10 nm, the wide pore width range allows the readily infiltration of reactant to access the inner surface, the sufficient interface reaction and release of produced bubbles, these surface characteristics are auxiliary factors for catalytic performances [53]. The morphology and microstructure of the typical NiFe@NC sample were characterized by scanning electrons microscopy (SEM) and high resolution transmittance electrons microscopy (HRTEM). The SEM mainly displays irregular blocks and large granulates with rough surface ( Fig. 3a), such a morphology is mainly due to the elimination of partial volatile groups from bamboo precursor and the embedding of tiny nanoparticles within the formed NC blocks [46], the overall morphology is largely similar to the bare NC sample (Fig. S1a). During the carbonization process, the lignin and cellulose experience dehydrogenation, deoxygenation and denitrogenation reactions and gradually carbonize to form NC with enriched pores. In addition, the metal ions undergo carbothermal reduction to form metal atoms, which are highly reactive and incline to fuse toward larger particles and coordinate with the nascent CN motif to reduce the surface Gibbs free energy. The alloy-NC interface interactions inhibit the over aggregation and lead to the tight embedding of tiny NiFe alloy nanoparticles within the NC motif with rough surface. Moreover, the as-formed alloys are catalyst for the graphitization of carbonaceous precursor [54], the molecular radicals by thermodecomposition of bamboo cellulose dissolve into the alloy and then gradually segregate outward to surface at annealing temperature, thus form graphitic carbon layers enwrapping around the alloy nanoparticles with high contact quality via the coordination effect of N sites, the sufficient interface interactions are beneficial for charge redistribution, thus forms electrophilic and nucleaphilic microregions that facilitate the chemisorption of electrolyte or reactants and interface charge transfer, therefore enhance the catalytic activity. To be mentioned, some porous channels survive the carbonization treatment, these macropores allow the filling of electrolyte and sustain the more sufficient interface reactions, therefore expedites the superficial catalytic reactions. Ni@NC, Co@NC, NiCo@NC and CoFe@NC also display irregular blocks (Fig. S1b∼e), showing the universality of this method for preparation of metals or alloys embedded NC hybrids. TEM of NiFe@NC mainly displays translucent porous carbonaceous network and dark particles (Fig. 3b), which are attributable respectively to the NC motif with low density and the NiFe alloy particles, these traits suggest the embedding of alloy within the carbonaceous network. The NiFe alloy component can not only increase the electric conductivity of the hybrid, but promote the chemisorption of reactants and interface reaction by virtue of the charge redistribution within the hybrid, both factors are conducive to catalytic performance. HRTEM (Fig. 3c) reveals that the NiFe alloy nanoparticles are encased by graphitic layers featuring curl fringes, manifesting the outward growth of graphitic layers catalyzed by NiFe alloy [40]. The light carbon layers relative to the beneath alloy particles is mainly due to the easily penetration of electrons beam across the thin shell composing of C, N elements with low atomic weights. The embedded alloy exhibits lattice fringes with spacing of 0.21 nm (inset), which correspond to the (111) planes of NiFe alloy [55]. Other regions of the carbon motif display no fringes, which imply that majority of the carbon motif is amorphous due to the fact that not all regions are formed by catalysis of alloy. The enriched defects and heteroelements doped network in most regions of NC motif result in disordered texture, as evidenced by the rather weak diffraction belonging to graphitic carbon (Fig. 2b). In this type of heterostructure, the coated graphitic layers effectively connect the alloy and the amorphous motif, thereby guarantees efficient metal-carbon electronic interactions, affinity to electrolyte and further the bifunctional catalytic behaviors [29]. From the high angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) coupled energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) mappings (Fig. 3d∼h), C, N, Ni, Fe elements are observable in the inspected region, which basically coincide with the elemental composition of NiFe@NC. More detailed observation reveals that the Ni, Fe distributions are almost fully overlapped, the fine correlation manifests the formation of NiFe alloy within the NC motif. In addition, the N element is homogeneously distributed throughout the carbonaceous motif, showing the successful self-doping by pyrolysis treatment. The homogeneously distributed N sites facilitate the embedding of alloy particles with high dispersity and tiny size within the NC network, which are beneficial for catalytic coherence and reproducibility. The chemical status of the typical NiFe@NC sample is identified by XPS, the survey spectrum illustrates the coexistence of C, N, O, Ni and Fe elements ( Fig. 4a) with atomic ratio of 54.9:6.6:30.3:4.2:4.0, which manifests the basic elemental composition of the sample. The high fraction of O element is mainly due to the survived oxygen containing groups in precursor and the inevitable surface oxidation of alloy. The N element content is also rather high, both O and N can increase the hydrophilicity of the carbonaceous framework, which is beneficial for catalytic property for water electrolysis. The detailed elemental forms are demonstrated by high resolution spectra, as illustrated in Fig, 4b, the C1s XPS can be resolved into three peaks attributable to CC/C-C framework (284.7 eV), C-N (285.7 eV) and CO bonds (287.8 eV) [51,56], the heteroelements can regulate the local electronic structure of carbon motif and form structural defects, as well as immobilize the metal/alloy component, the triple roles therefore facilitate the catalytic performance. Fig. 4c shows the N1s XPS, the N element exists in form of pyridinic- (398.1 eV), Ni(Fe)-N (398.8 eV), pyrrolic- (399.5 eV), graphitic- (400.6 eV) and oxidized- N (402.4 eV) [37,57], showing the incorporation of N into different positions of carbon framework and the binding with metals. In the diversified N forms, the pyridinic- and pyrrolic- N sites can anchor the alloy via coordination interactions, while the graphitic-N with delocalized electron is beneficial for electric conductivity, all of these characteristics are capable of reducing the resistances during the electrochemical process and ensuring high catalytic activities. O1s XPS (Fig. 4d) shows two peaks at binding energies (BEs) of 531.7 and 532.8 eV assignable respectively to the -OH and CO bonds, suggesting the survival of partial of these groups during pyrolysis process and the formation of Ni(Fe) hydroxides [58,59], which are beneficial for hydrophilicity. The forms of Ni element are revealed by Ni2p XPS, as illustrated in Fig. 4e, the peaks at 856.1 and 873.8 eV are assignable to the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 spin orbits of Ni(II) form [42,60], and the two wide satellites peaks are attributable to the spin coupling of unpaired electrons within Ni(II). The absence of Ni(0) is inconsistent with the XRD result, which is mainly due to the electrons diffusion to NC motif across the N coordination sites, and the surface oxidation upon exposure to air. In term of Fe2p XPS, the spectrum can be fitted into Fe(0) (707 and 719 eV) and Fe(III) (712.5 and 725.6 eV) [61,62], these results indicate the diversified Fe forms. Relative to Ni, the presence of Fe(0) suggests that the reactivity of Ni is higher over Fe, which can alleviate the oxidation of Fe in alloy. From these results, the enhanced oxidation values of Ni, Fe elements are beneficial for the affinity to OH- ions and the acceptance of electrons, these species are possible catalytic sites for alkali OER. The electronic interaction between NiFe alloy and NC support, as well as the energy level structure of the NiFe@NC hybrid were further investigated by means of ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy (UPS) and ultraviolet-visible diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV-Vis). Fig. 5a shows the UPS of NiFe alloy and NC support, calculated from the extrapolated secondary cutoff edge to baseline according to: EФ =hv-(Ecutoff-Efermi) [30], assuming the energy level of free electrons is 0 eV (EФ =0 eV) in both cases, the Fermi level (Efermi) of NiFe alloy is − 2.9 eV, which is higher over that of NC (−3.5 eV). Moreover, the valence band (VB) of NC is 0.95 eV beneath its Efermi from the near Fermi edge (inset), and the optical band gap is 1.25 eV from the Tauc curve derived from UV-Vis (Fig. 5b), evidencing the semiconductor nature of NC. Hence, a Mott-Schottky junction can be formed upon intimate contact of NiFe alloy and NC. The energy levels of both components prior to contact are illustrated in Fig. 5c, the apparently higher Efermi of NiFe alloy over NC is the driving force for interface charge redistribution. Upon intimate contact (Fig. 5d), the spontaneous diffusion of electrons from NiFe alloy to NC causes the downshifted Efermi of the former whereas the upshifted energy levels of the latter, till the balanced state with alligned Efermis [31,32]. The charge redistribution results in the energy band bending at the interface, namely, the upshifted conduction band (CB) of NC support reinforces its reducibility for HER. In addition, due to the Fermi level of embedded NiFe alloy (higher over −3.5 eV) is also higher over the potential of alkali water reduction (2H2O+2e=H2+2OH- (1 M KOH), Eθ = −0.83 V or − 3.67 eV), the NiFe alloy component can also reduce water molecule from the perspective of energy level, despite the electrophilic surface. Hence, both components are potential catalytic sites for alkali HER in this work. On the other hand, the Fermi level of NiFe alloy and VB of NC in the hybrid are higher over the potential of alkali water oxidation (O2+2H2O+4e=4OH- (1 M KOH), Eθ = 0.4 V or − 4.9 eV), so the NiFe@NC itself is incapable of catalyzing OER in essence. Other species, such as the surface bimetallic oxides or (oxy)hydroxides of Ni, Fe elements with high oxidation values may be the possible sites for alkali OER. 3.3 Alkali OER properties The OER catalytic behaviors of the typical NiFe@NC electrode was tested in 1 M KOH aqueous electrolyte in 3-electrode system. Prior to the test, 100 successive CVs were performed within 1–1.6 V at 10 mV s−1 to achieve a stable OER current response. As demonstrated in Fig. 6a, the J over 1.5 V elevates gradually and then retains stable with CV cycles, which suggest the enhanced OER efficiency due to the activation of metal sites at high potential, the elevated redox peaks within 1.3–1.5 V belonging to redox of Ni, Fe sites also evidence the gradual oxidation and activation of metal sites. The gradually formed (oxy)hydroxide during the successive electrooxidation at high potential is deemed to be responsible for the OER efficiency [63,64]. In addition, the synergy between Ni, Fe (oxy)hydroxide is also conducive to OER catalysis [42,53,65], hence the activation treatment is essential for OER property. The OER behaviors of activated electrodes were initially evaluated by LSVs at 5 mVs−1 without IR compensation. As shown in Fig. 6b, all of the curves include an anodic peak due to the oxidation of metal sites and a prompt OER response, the OER onset potentials of NiFe@NC and CoFe@NC electrodes are earlier than the rest ones including RuO2, which suggest that the synergy by Fe is highly essential for OER. Hereinto, the OER onset potential of NiFe@NC is the lowest and the J at each potential is substantially higher over other electrodes, showing the highest OER catalytic activity. Relative to the weak OER property of NC electrode, the prominent efficiency of NiFe@NC suggests that the embedded NiFe alloy, more concretely the surface (oxy)hydroxide layer is vital for for OER. Quantitatively, the overpotential at 10 mA cm−2 (η 10) is 270 mV at NiFe@NC electrode, which is lower than CoFe@NC electrode (η 10 =288 mV) and substantially lower than other electrodes, showing the maximized catalytic efficiency by embedding of NiFe alloy into NC motif. To be mentioned, in term of alloy embedded NC hybrids, the η 10s of NiFe@NC and CoFe@NC electrodes are significantly lower than NiCo@NC electrode (η 10 =375 mV), highlighting the vital role of Fe in these alloys embedded NC hybrids. The promoting effect is presumably due to the electrons diffusion from Ni(Co) to Fe across the oxygen bridge in lattice, the elevated oxidation values of Ni(Co) site with eg orbit electron occupancy close to 1 ensures the chemisorption of OH- ions and associated intermediates with optimal bond strength, therefore maximize the catalytic activity [66]. The OER properties of Ni2Fe@NC and NiFe2@NC electrodes are also evaluated by LSVs (Fig. 6c), the Js at arbitrary potential follow the order: NiFe@NC>Ni2Fe@NC>NiFe2@NC, showing the typical NiFe@NC is the optimal OER catalyst herein, as verifed by the results of C dl s in Fig. S2. By 85% IR compensation (Fig. 6d), the η 10 of NiFe@NC electrode reduces to 257 mV, also showcases the good OER catalytic capability. Relative to the η 10s of 353 and 330 mV for Ni@NC and Co@NC electrodes, the substantially reduced η 10s of NiFe@NC (257 mV) and CoFe@NC (273 mV) electrodes manifest the prominent promoting effect of the incorporated Fe. Fig. 6e summaries the η 10s and the Js at 1.70 V (J 1.7s) of different electrodes collected from non-IR compensated LSVs, the η 10 of NiFe@NC electrode is lower than and the J 1.7 is higher over other electrodes including RuO2 electrode, showing the potential of NiFe@NC as highly active non-precious OER catalyst. The η 10 of NiFe@NC electrode is also lower than other alloys (metals) embedded NC hybrids documented previously, such as hcp-Co@NC (η 10 =290 mV) [45], NiFe@NCNFs (η 10 =294 mV, IR compensated) [46], tubular assembly of NiFe@NCNT (η 10 =315 mV, IR compensated) [54], polyphthalocyanine derived NiFe@NC (η 10 =350 mV, IR compensated) [67], comparable to CoFe@NCNT (η 10 =257 mV IR compensated) [40], whereas inferior to the grapefruit peel derived NiFe@NC/NGC (η 50 =287 mV, IR compensated) [36] and NiFe@NC/RGO (η 10 =223 mV, IR compensated) [50]. From these comparisons, the NiFe@NC herein is a qualified catalyst for OER. To further understand the OER kinetics at different electrodes, Tafel plots of the electrodes were obtained in form of η vs logJ correlations. As depicted in Fig. 6f, the Tafel slopes of the NiFe@NC and CoFe@NC electrodes are both 63 mV dec−1, which are lower than that of Ni@NC, Co@NC, NiCo@NC, NC and RuO2 electrodes (115, 78, 141, 93 and 135 mV dec−1, respectively). Given the lowest η and Tafel slope, the fastest OER occurs at NiFe@NC electrode. In addition, EISs of the electrodes were measured at 1.6 V. From Fig. 6 g, the Nyquist impedances of all electrodes display defined semicircles with different diameters, showing the different OER kinetics at various electrodes. In general, the real axis intercept at high frequency end represents the series resistance (R s ) of electrode, which encompasses the electric resistance of catalyst, the ionic resistance of electrolyte and the ohmic resistance between current collector and catalyst [53,68]. The R s s of alloys embedded NC electrodes are slightly higher over the monometal embedded counterparts, which are presumably due to the more disordered structures of the embedded alloys within NC motif slightly reduce the electronic mobilities. But in all, the discrepancies in R s s are rather marginal, so the influence to OER kinetics are minor. The high frequency arc reflects the charge transfer resistance (R ct) at electrode-reactant interface, namely the OER rate at catalyst surface, the smaller diameter of the arc implies the lower R ct value, viz the more rapid OER kinetics [45,65]. Fitted by the equivalent circuit in inset, the R ct of NiFe@NC electrode is 0.24 ohm, which is lower than that of Ni@NC (0.52 ohm), Co@NC (0.32 ohm), NiCo@NC (0.39 ohm) and CoFe@NC (0.44 ohm) electrodes, these outcomes also symbolize the more rapid charge transfer rate, namely the higher OER efficiency at NiFe@NC electrode. The accessible catalytic sites are also pivotal factor determining the OER catalytic efficiency, so the ECSAs of the electrodes were estimated using C dl as an indicator [69]. The C dl can be roughly estimated by the CVs within non-faradic potential range at various scan rates (Fig. S2 and S3). As summarized in Fig. 6 h, the ΔJ/2 s show good linearities to the scan rates for all electrodes, the slopes of plots equal the C dl s. Concretely, the C dl s are 2, 28, 2, 18 and 16 mF cm−2, respectively for Ni@NC, Co@NC, NiCo@NC, NiFe@NC and CoFe@NC electrodes, and the corresponding ECSAs are 50, 700, 50, 450 and 400 cm2, respectively, showing the different contributions of ECSAs to OER efficiencies. Benefitted by the enriched catalytic sites for the high C dl and the catalytic activity of surface (oxy)hydroxide layer of alloy component [69], the NiFe@NC herein offers the highest OER efficiency. The catalytic stability is another essential parameter vital for actual application, which can be evaluated by V-t curve. As shown in Fig. 6i, η 10 of NiFe@NC electrode increases gradually to 282 mV upon 24 h of operation, the inconspicuous increment indicates the slight decay in catalytic efficiency, which is benefitted from the unique core-shell structure, the NC shell can protect the alloy from corrosion and aggregation during electrochemical process. In addition, the LSVs of NiFe@NC electrode before and after 3000 successive CVs are compared (inset), the OER potential slightly lags after CV cycles, also evidences the good electrochemical stability upon repeated OER cycles. The morphological and structural variations of NiFe@NC electrode after 24 h of V-t test were monitored. From Fig. S4a, the SEM still displays aggregated particulates with rough surface, showing the largely remaining of its initial morphology free of obvious collapse or exfoliation. The XRD pattern inherits the initial metallic phase free of any additional diffractions (Fig. S4b), which implies the surface (oxy)hydroxide layer of alloy component is amorphous, such a surface layer may facilitate the retention of OER catalytic activity. The absence of defined vibrations ascribable to Ni(Fe)-OH bonds (around 500 cm−1) in Raman spectrum (Fig. S4c) also suggests the amorphous structure of surface (oxy)hydroxide layer. The inconspicuous structural alterations are thought to be beneficial for the OER stability. Moreover, the inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry of electrolyte shows the Ni, Fe concentrations of 50.2 and 38.7 μg L−1, respectively, the slight dissolution of alloy component in electrolyte is assumed to be the main cause for the gradual decay in OER activity. Besides the chemical catalytic behaviors, the physical features of electrode surface, namely the hydrophilicity and aerophobicity are additional factors facilitating the rapid infiltration of electrolyte for OER and the release of generated O2 bubbles [70,71]. Hence, the water and O2 bubble contact angles (CAs) of the NiFe@NC electrode were determined. As shown in Fig. 7a and Video S1, the dangling water drop (1 M KOH) infiltrates and spreads quickly into/onto NiFe@NC electrode upon contact, the low water CA of 8.9 ° manifests the excellent wettability to alkali electrolyte [72], which ensures the sufficient interface OER. In addition, the underwater O2 bubble CA of the electrode is rather high (148.3 °, Fig. 7b), which is higher over the Ni foam substrate (O2 bubble CA of 135.8 °, Fig. 7c), showing the good aerophobicity of the NiFe@NC catalyst, which promotes the rapid release of nascent O2 bubbles before accumulation, merging into larger bubbles that severely mask the surface sites, thereby ensures high catalytic activity from surface perspective. As visually demonstrated in Fig. 7d, tiny O2 bubbles (less than 1 mm in size) release rapidly from the NiFe@NC electrode at J= 100 mA cm−2, suggesting the rapid escape of generated O2 bubbles, the re-exposure of more catalytic sites to electrolyte is beneficial for OER. Comprehensive considering the high catalytic activity for OER, the highly hydrophilic, aerophobic surface and the rapid release of tiny O2 bubbles, efficient OER at NiFe@NC electrode is reasonable. Supplementary material related to this article can be found online at doi:10.1016/j.apcata.2022.118984. The following is the Supplementary material related to this article Video S1. Video S1 . 3.4 Alkali HER properties Likewise, the electrochemical behaviors of different electrodes for HER were also measured in the same electrolyte, and commercial Pt/C electrode was also compared. Fig. 8a presents the LSVs at 5 mV s−1 without IR compensation, the HER current responses of the as-prepared catalytic electrodes are inferior to the Pt/C electrode to different degrees. Despite this, the η of NiFe@NC electrode is lower than the other non-Pt electrodes, showing the good HER efficiency of the former electrode. The LSV responses of NiFe@NC electrode is also superior to Ni2Fe@NC and NiFe2@NC electrodes (Fig. 8b), hence, the NiFe@NC electrode herein is the optimal candidate for HER. Fig. 8c summarizes the HER response current densities at − 0.4 V (J -0.4s) and η 10s (overpotentials at J=−10 mA cm−2) of different electrodes. Amongst them, the NiFe@NC electrode exhibits J -0.4 = 60 mA cm−2, which is higher over other non-precious catalytic electrodes, such as Ni@NC (J -0.4 =26 mA cm−2), Co@NC (J -0.4 =59 mA cm−2), NiCo@NC (J -0.4 =35 mA cm−2) and CoFe@NC (J -0.4 =45 mA cm−2), showing the good HER catalytic property of the former electrode. Besides, the NiFe@NC electrode also displays the smallest η 10 (206 mV) except the Pt/C electrode. The η 10 value can be further reduced to 182 mV by 85% IR compensation (Fig. S5), which is comparable to that of Ni@NC (η 10 =205 mV), Co@NC (η 10 =183 mV), NiCo@NC (η 10 =182 mV) and CoFe@NC (η 10 =173 mV), these results also evidence the good HER catalytic activity of the former electrode to some extent. Fig. 8d compares the Tafel plots of the electrodes derived from non-compensated LSVs, the Tafel slopes are 123, 159, 105, 95, 178, 77 and 58 mV dec−1, respectively for Ni@NC, Co@NC, NiCo@NC, NiFe@NC, CoFe@NC, NC and Pt/C electrodes, the lower value of NiFe@NC electrode over its cousins suggests the rapid HER kinetics at the former electrode. The Tafel slopes of non-Pt electrodes are close to 120 mV dec−1, so it is assumed that the HER kinetics at these electrodes are limited by Volmer step, namely the initial adsorptive reduction of OH- or H2O by an electron toward free H atom (H2O+*+e-=*-H+OH-, * represents the catalytic site) is the rate limiting step [73,74]. Due to the surperficial hydroxides of alloy facilitate the chemisorption of OH- ions, and the reductive NC support and alloy components facilitate the stabilization of produced H atoms, the followed coupling of H atoms toward H2 can be ensured. Fig. 8e depicts the V-t plots of NiFe@NC electrodes at − 10 mA cm−2, the η 10 value enlarges from 203 to 243 after 20 h of operation, the nonsevere decay in HER efficiency suggests the acceptable HER catalytic stability. 3.5 Full water electrolysis performances In view of the good OER and HER catalytic efficiencies, the NiFe@NC holds the potential as bifunctional catalyst for full water electrolysis. Hence the water electrolysis performance of the symmetric NiFe@NC//NiFe@NC electrolyzer was measured in the same 1 M KOH electrolyte, and the asymmetric electrolyzer based on RuO2 anode and Pt/C cathode (denoted as RuO2//Pt/C) was also measured for comparison. Fig. 9a presents the LSVs of the two devices at 5 mV s−1, the NiFe@NC//NiFe@NC electrolyzer needs an input voltage (V 10) of 1.75 V to arise an overall water electrolysis response of J= 10 mA cm−2, which is inferior to the RuO2//Pt/C device (1.68 V). With the enlargement of input voltage, the J of the former device elevates more prominently, showing the more pronounced water electrolysis at higher voltage, the J of the former device surpasses the RuO2//Pt/C electrolyzer over 1.88 V, which implies the higher H2 and O2 generation rates at the NiFe@NC electrodes under higher driving voltage. As quantified by water drainage method, the generated H2, O2 amounts at cathode and anode electrodes are close to their theoretical values under a high voltage of 2.5 V (Fig. 9b), the FEs are 98.4% and 97.1% for cathodic hydrogen and anodic oxygen productions, which manifest the complete water electrolysis with minor side reactions. The catalytic durability of the NiFe@NC//NiFe@NC electrolyzer was also assessed by V-t curve at J= 10 mA cm−2. As shown in Fig. 9c, V 10 increases slightly from 1.75 to 1.79 V, the 40 mV increment upon 24 h of operation implies the good stabilities of NiFe@NC at both electrodes. Given the facile preparation of NiFe@NC and the acceptable catalytic efficiencies for OER and HER, the NiFe@NC herein is a promising bifunctional catalyst for full water electrolysis. 4 Conclusions In summary, NiFe@NC with embedding of NiFe alloy within bamboo derived NC was prepared as bifunctional catalyst for water electrolysis. Benefited from the sufficient alloy-NC electronic interaction, surface oxidation of alloy component, and the hydrophilic, aerophobic surface with high SBET, efficient chemisorption of reactants and interface charge transfer can be ensured, which are beneficial for bifunctional catalytic behaviors. As a consequence, the NiFe@NC electrode demonstrated high catalytic efficiencies for OER and HER. The symmetric water electrolyzer based on NiFe@NC catalyst demonstrated moderate driving voltage, high FEs and robust durability for alkali water electrolysis. The current work provides a feasible way to enhance the bifunctional catalytic activities for water electrolysis via alloy embedded carbonaceous hybrids. coredata.dc:description: Metal-support electronic interaction is a feasible way to enhance the catalytic activity and bifunctionality for oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), and further the easily water electrolysis for hydrogen production at low cost. Herein, NiFe alloy embedded in N doped carbon support hybrid (NiFe@NC) was prepared by pyrolysis of metal ions impregnated bamboo precursor. In this NiFe@NC hybrid, the surface (oxy)hydroxide layer of alloy led to high OER efficiency (overpotential of 270 mV at 10 mA cm−2), and the alloy-support interaction enabled high catalytic efficiency for HER (overpotential of 206 mV at −10 mA cm−2). Benefitted by the bifunctional features, the symmetric water electrolyzer based on two identical NiFe@NC electrodes demonstrated acceptable input voltage and high faradaic efficiencies (FEs) for water electrolysis. The current work offers a feasible showcase for fulfilling of bifunctional catalyses in water electrolysis via the metal-support electronic interaction.
coredata.dc:title: Nickel iron alloy embedded, nitrogen doped porous carbon catalyst for efficient water electrolysis
